title: WCAS HISTORY 395-0-22 Research Seminar

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Medieval saints and sinners were embodiments of the struggle between good and evil. But these polarities were never stable. The worst sinners frequently made the best saints: throughout the Middle Ages, society was fascinated by the drama of moral conversion expressed in the lives of the legendary "prostitute" saints. But conceptions of sanctity and sin also fluctuated in response to social change. Once Christianity became the dominant religion, tales of martyrdom gave way to acts of self-mortification. By the same token, sin tended to be assessed in terms of actions and their consequences in the early Middle Ages. In the twelfth century, however, there was a revolutionary emphasis on conscience that tended to locate sin in the intention. Society's spiritual heroes and sinful ne'er do wells constitute prisms through which the moral universe is refracted.
